questions.question_text: Which kind of SSAE audit reviews controls dealing with the organization's controls for assuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data?
questions.answer_description: SOC 2 deals with the CIA triad. SOC 1 is for financial reporting. SOC 3 is only an attestation by the auditor. There is no SOC 4.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A SOC 2 (System and Organization Controls 2) audit reviews an organizationâ€™s controls for assuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data. It is based on the AICPA's Trust Services Criteria (TSC), which include:

Security
Availability
Processing Integrity
Confidentiality
Privacy
SOC 2 reports are typically used by cloud service providers (CSPs), SaaS companies, and data processors to demonstrate compliance with security and data protection requirements.

Why Not the Others?
A. SOC 1 â†’ Focuses on financial reporting controls, not IT security or data protection.
C. SOC 3 â†’ A publicly available summary of a SOC 2 report but without detailed security controls.
D. SOC 4 â†’ Does not exist in the SSAE auditing framework.

questions.answer_description: While the provider might share any of the other options listed, the provider will not share administration of security controls with the customer. Security controls are the sole province of the provider.
questions.question_text: To address shared monitoring and testing responsibilities in a cloud configuration, the provider might offer all these to the cloud customer except:

choices.A: Access to audit logs and performance data

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In a shared monitoring and testing model within a cloud environment, cloud providers typically offer visibility into security controls, logs, and administrative functions. However, DLP (Data Loss Prevention) solution results are generally not provided by the cloud provider because:

DLP is typically a customer-side control, meaning the customer manages and implements DLP policies.
Cloud providers focus on infrastructure security, while DLP focuses on data-level security within the customer's environment.
DLP results are highly sensitive and specific to an organizationâ€™s data policies, and sharing them could pose security and privacy risks.
Agree, It's a silly misleading question
This is from official book, chapter 6. Security control administration is correct answer per book as well.
To be fair none of these make much sense to me...
Does option D makes any sense ?

comments.content: I figured it was put in just to confuse everyone, makes no sense. Bad question.

questions.answer_description:
The SOC 3 is the least detailed, so the provider is not concerned about revealing it. The SOC 1 Types 1 and 2 are about financial reporting and not relevant. The
SOC 2 Type 2 is much more detailed and will most likely be kept closely held by the provider.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A SOC 2 Type 2 audit report is the most beneficial for a cloud customer because it evaluates a cloud providerâ€™s security controls over time, specifically covering the Trust Services Criteria (TSC):

âœ” Security â€“ Protection against unauthorized access.
âœ” Availability â€“ Ensuring systems are operational.
âœ” Processing Integrity â€“ Accurate and reliable data processing.
âœ” Confidentiality â€“ Controlled access to sensitive data.
âœ” Privacy â€“ Compliance with privacy regulations.

ðŸ”¹ Why Itâ€™s Unlikely the Provider Will Share It?

SOC 2 Type 2 reports contain detailed security control assessments, which are often confidential and shared only with existing customers under NDAs.
Cloud providers prefer to provide SOC 3 reports, which are public summaries of SOC 2 findings.

Selected Answer: C
C. SOC 2 Type 2

questions.question_text: Which kind of SSAE audit report is most beneficial for a cloud customer, even though it's unlikely the cloud provider will share it?

choices.A: Many states have data breach notification laws.
choices.C: Breaches can cause the loss of intellectual property.
choices.B: Breaches can cause the loss of proprietary data.
choices.D: Legal liability can't be transferred to the cloud provider.

questions.answer_description: State notification laws and the loss of proprietary data/intellectual property pre-existed the cloud; only the lack of ability to transfer liability is new.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Why Not the Others?
B. Breaches can cause the loss of proprietary data. â†’ This is a concern in any environment, not a new factor unique to the cloud.
C. Breaches can cause the loss of intellectual property. â†’ Similar to B, this is a general risk, not specific to cloud migration.
D. Legal liability can't be transferred to the cloud provider. â†’ While true in most cases, cloud contracts can define liability limits, making this a contractual issue rather than a direct BIA factor.

Selected Answer: A
After migrating to the cloud, organizations must update their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) to consider new compliance and regulatory risks, particularly data breach notification laws.

ðŸ”¹ Why Are Data Breach Notification Laws Important in the Cloud?

Many U.S. states and international jurisdictions (e.g., GDPR, CCPA) require organizations to notify affected individuals and regulators in the event of a breach.
Cloud environments introduce shared security responsibilities, making compliance with data breach notification timelines and processes more complex.
Failure to comply can result in legal penalties, reputational damage, and financial losses.

Selected Answer: D
D. Legal liability can't be transferred to the cloud provider.

questions.question_text: When reviewing the BIA after a cloud migration, the organization should take into account new factors related to data breach impacts. One of these new factors is:

questions.answer_description: Elasticity is the name for the benefit of cloud computing where resources can be apportioned as necessary to meet customer demand. Obfuscation is a technique to hide full raw datasets, either from personnel who do not have need to know or for use in testing. Mobility is not a term pertinent to the CBK.
questions.question_text: What is the term we use to describe the general ease and efficiency of moving data from one cloud provider either to another cloud provider or down from the cloud?
